Comment:
My opponent played well, but in the end played for a draw when a win was inevitable for White in a R&K vs. K ending.  The strategy will be explained when we get down to R&K vs. K.
As a B/C player, I stick to a few openings, only experimenting when playing against players that I know I dominate.  Here, I chose my standard Scandinavian.  The idea is to challenge White from the very first move.
Black is a pawn down, but gets a little lead in development.  The gambit of the pawn is temporary.
Black is a pawn down, but gets a little lead in development.  The gambit of the pawn is temporary.
The Modern Variation.  Jack Peters, the IM and LA Times Chess columnist, taught me this opening in a series of private lessons.
White develops with check.  It is a book move.
This, though, is bad.  White has made two moves with a piece that is now about to vanish from play.  A waste of time.  After Black retakes, he'll have two pieces developed to White's none.

I'm pretty sure a master would find fault with these moves.  But Black is wanting to recapture the piece and control the center.  Black also worries a bit about getting castled.

Black makes this move to give his opponent an ugly pawn formation.  The isolated a pawn and the doubled c pawns are liabilities that can provide dividends in the end game.

This looks like a wasted move.  "Every tempi counts!" Jack Peters would say.  Black had no threat to occupy g4.
